Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Embeddings of discrete metric spaces into Banach spaces
Award.AbstractNarration:
Embeddings of discrete metric spaces into Banach spaces is by now a well-established tool in Theoretical Computer Science and Topology. In Theoretical Computer Science embeddings are used to construct, sometimes the best known, approximation algorithms. In Topology embeddings are used to prove special cases of the Novikov conjecture and the Baum-Connes conjecture. Nevertheless, some of the important problems on embeddings remain open. The main purpose of the project is to achieve progress on problems of the following types. Determine to what extent presence of expander-like structures is the only obstruction to coarse embeddings of spaces with bounded geometry into a Hilbert space. Determine to what extent expanders and graphs with large girth resist nontrivially good embeddings. Determine to what extent the Hilbert space is the most difficult space to embed into. Find characterizations of well-known classes of Banach spaces in terms of embeddings.

Analysis of large sets of data is important in many contexts. Usually data is endowed with a natural distance (degree of dissimilarity) of its elements. One of the useful approaches to analysis of such sets of data is to use some low-distortion embeddings of the set into a space whose structure is well-known, for example into a two-dimensional or three-dimensional space. After that one can use many algorithms available in computational geometry and many tools from such classical parts of mathematics as Calculus. In some cases one can even visualize the structure of the set, for example, see its clusters. Unfortunately the existence of a low-distortion embedding into a plane is rather rare in applications. In many contexts much weaker (than low-distortion) types of embeddings are still useful, and even embeddings into high-dimensional or infinite-dimensional generalizations of the three-dimensional space lead to important results. Constructions and analysis of such embeddings is the main goal of the proposal.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The principal investigator worked on problems in the theory of embeddings of metric spaces into Banach spaces.

During the reporting period the PI wrote and published a book "Metric embeddings" containing an introduction to this research area. This book made the research area more accessible; it is already used by many researchers for work with graduate students, self-study, and as a reference. A review of this book recently appeared (02/02/2016) in the "Bulletin of the American Mathematical Society".

The PI organized a biweekly research seminar for those students at St. John's University who are planning to get into Ph.D. programs in mathematics. Work of this seminar resulted in publication (by Hiu Fai Law, Siu Lam Leung, and the PI) of a paper on spanning tree congestion in the journal "Involve" (2014) and a submission of the paper (by Siu Lam Leung, Sarah Nelson, Sofiya Ostrovska, and the PI) on the distortion of embeddings of binary trees into diamond graphs to the journal "Colloquium Mathematicum". In Fall 2015 Siu Lam Leung was accepted to the Ph. D. program at the Kent State University.

For applications of metric embeddings it is important to know how well different classes of metric spaces are embeddable into different classes of Banach spaces. In a joint paper with Beata Randrianantoanina, the PI found new classes of metric spaces which admit low-distortion embeddings into all n-dimensional Banach spaces.

One of the most important achievements of the PI in the reporting period is discovery of the metric characterizations of the Radon-Nikodym property. By a `metric characterization' we mean a characterization in purely metric terms, not involving the linear structure of the space.

The PI also found metric characterizations of reflexivity, infinite tree property, and  contributed to the study of metric characterizations of superreflexivity. In particular the PI characterized superreflexivity in terms of embeddability of hyperbolic groups, found connections between the metric characterization of superreflexivity and the Radon-Nikodym property, and showed that previously known characterizations of superreflexivity, in terms of binary trees, diamond graphs, and Laakso graphs, do not directly follow from each other (the latest version of the result on binary trees and diamond graphs is joint with Siu Lam Leung, Sarah Nelson, and Sofiya Ostrovska).
